question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, the Republican primary race for the 2024 US Presidential Election is well underway. The leading candidates for the Republican nomination are former President Donald Trump, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, and several other prominent Republican figures. Donald Trump Jr. has not declared his candidacy for the presidency, nor has there been significant speculation or credible reports suggesting he intends to run. His political activities have primarily been focused on supporting his father's campaign and engaging in political commentary.

Donald Trump Jr. has never held elected office, which could be a substantial hurdle in securing the nomination, especially when competing against experienced politicians with established political careers. Furthermore, it is unlikely that he would run against his father if Donald Trump Sr. remains in the race. The Republican National Convention typically selects nominees who have demonstrated political leadership and have broad support within the party.

Given these factors, the probability of Donald Trump Jr. being selected as the Republican nominee is extremely low. While unforeseen events could always occur, there is currently little to suggest that he will become the nominee.

question.title: Will Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Asa Hutchinson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. metadata.chain_of_thought:
Asa Hutchinson, the former Governor of Arkansas, has declared his candidacy for the Republican nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election. As of October 2023, he has been polling very low in national surveys, typically registering around 1% or less of the Republican primary electorate's support. The leading candidates for the nomination are former President Donald Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, who have significantly higher name recognition, fundraising capabilities, and established support within the party base.

Donald Trump remains the frontrunner despite facing legal challenges, maintaining a strong and loyal base. Ron DeSantis is considered a prominent alternative to Trump, with substantial backing from influential party members and donors. Other candidates like Nikki Haley and Mike Pence also have higher visibility and support compared to Hutchinson.

Asa Hutchinson lacks the national profile, campaign infrastructure, and financial resources that are typically necessary to secure a major party nomination. There have been no significant shifts in the political landscape indicating a surge in his popularity or campaign momentum. Given these factors, the likelihood of him being selected as the Republican nominee by the delegates at the Republican National Convention is extremely low.

question.title: Will both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson be selected as the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Donald Trump Jr. has not announced any intention to run for the Republican nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election. There are no credible reports or indications that he plans to enter the race. Asa Hutchinson, the former Governor of Arkansas, has declared his candidacy but is polling very low compared to leading candidates like former President Donald Trump and others. The Republican National Convention typically selects one nominee for President, and the Vice Presidential nominee is usually chosen by the Presidential nominee and then confirmed by the convention delegates. It is highly unlikely for both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson to be simultaneously selected as the Presidential and Vice Presidential nominees under these circumstances. Given these factors, the probability that both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson will be selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election is extremely low.

question.title: Will either Donald Trump Jr. or Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Donald Trump Jr. or Asa Hutchinson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, the Republican primary for the 2024 US Presidential Election is well underway. Former President Donald Trump Sr. remains the clear frontrunner, leading by a significant margin in national polls. Other notable candidates include Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, Vivek Ramaswamy, and Chris Christie.

**Donald Trump Jr.:**
- **Candidacy Status:** Donald Trump Jr. has not declared his candidacy for the 2024 presidential election.
- **Likelihood of Entering the Race:** There is no substantial evidence or indication that he intends to enter the race at this late stage.
- **Political Involvement:** While he is active politically, his involvement is primarily in supporting his father's campaign and engaging with conservative media.

**Asa Hutchinson:**
- **Candidacy Status:** Asa Hutchinson, the former governor of Arkansas, officially announced his candidacy in April 2023.
- **Poll Standing:** He is polling extremely low, often registering at or below 1% in national polls.
- **Campaign Momentum:** There has been little to no traction gained by his campaign. No significant endorsements, fundraising breakthroughs, or debate performances have shifted his standing.
- **Competition:** The race has been dominated by higher-profile candidates who have more substantial support bases and resources.

**Additional Considerations:**
- **Delays and Withdrawals:** The Republican National Convention is scheduled for July 2024. With less than a year remaining, major shifts in candidate standings become increasingly unlikely.
- **Unexpected Events:** While unexpected events can occur (e.g., candidates dropping out, scandals), the probability that such events would specifically advantage either Donald Trump Jr. or Asa Hutchinson is exceedingly low.
- **Succession of Support:** If Donald Trump Sr. were to exit the race for any reason, it is more plausible that his support would shift to established candidates like Ron DeSantis or another prominent figure rather than Donald Trump Jr., who is not a declared candidate.

**Conclusion:**
Given the current political landscape, polling data, and the status of both individuals, the likelihood that either Donald Trump Jr. or Asa Hutchinson will be selected as the Republican nominee is extremely low. There is no current evidence to suggest a forthcoming change that would elevate either candidate to frontrunner status.

Considering Pence's low polling numbers, the lack of a campaign from Cruz, and the overall dynamics of the Republican primary race, the likelihood that either Mike Pence or Ted Cruz becomes the Republican nominee is very low.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, President Joe Biden has officially declared his intention to run for re-election in the 2024 presidential race. Here are the key factors influencing the likelihood of him announcing that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination before July 15, 2024:

1. **Incumbency Advantage**: Incumbent presidents often seek re-election due to the advantages they hold, such as higher visibility and established political networks. Biden's administration would likely want to leverage these advantages to retain the presidency.

2. **Party Support**: The Democratic Party has largely rallied behind Biden, with no significant primary challengers as of my last update. A strong unified front reduces the likelihood of Biden stepping down.

3. **Age and Health Considerations**: Biden is the oldest sitting president in U.S. history. Concerns about his age and potential health issues could arise. If health problems were to emerge, it might prompt him to reconsider his candidacy. However, there have been no official reports indicating serious health issues.

4. **Political Climate**: Unexpected shifts in the political landscape, such as significant drops in approval ratings, major scandals, or emerging strong opposition within the party, could influence his decision. However, absent any major developments, this seems unlikely.

5. **Historical Precedent**: It is rare for incumbent presidents to decline their party's nomination. The most notable example is President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1968, who withdrew due to the Vietnam War's unpopularity and internal party divisions.

6. **Strategic Timing**: Announcing a withdrawal before July 15, 2024, would give the Democratic Party time to select and rally behind an alternative candidate. However, a late withdrawal could be detrimental to the party's chances in the general election, which Biden and his advisors would likely seek to avoid.

Based on these factors, while there is a possibility that unforeseen circumstances could lead to Biden withdrawing his candidacy, the likelihood is relatively low given the current information.

question.title: Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday August 9th at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Vice President Kamala Harris is serving under President Joe Biden, who has announced his intention to run for re-election in the 2024 presidential election. Unless there is a significant change in circumstances, it is expected that President Biden will be the Democratic nominee, with Kamala Harris potentially continuing as his running mate.

Nate Silver's election models typically focus on the main presidential candidates rather than vice-presidential candidates unless they become the nominee. If Kamala Harris were to become the Democratic nominee due to unforeseen circumstances (e.g., President Biden deciding not to run or being unable to continue his campaign), her Electoral College probabilities would then be directly modeled.

Assuming that Kamala Harris becomes the nominee and is included in Nate Silver's model, the probability of her Electoral College odds increasing over the next week would depend on various factors such as changes in polling data, campaign developments, debates, or significant news events. Given the short time frame of one week and the lack of specific indicators pointing toward a substantial shift in her favor, it seems unlikely that there would be a significant increase in her odds within that period.

Therefore, considering the uncertainties and the information available up to my knowledge cutoff, I would estimate a low probability that Kamala Harris's Electoral College probability in Nate Silver's model will exceed 46.6% on Friday, August 9th at 8:40 PM.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, AND will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
(1) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? This resolves as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the nomination in the 2024 election cycle. If such a statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this resolves as No.

(2) Will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model? This resolves as Yes if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday, August 9th, at 8:40 PM. Resolves No otherwise.

This question will resolve as Yes if both (1) and (2) resolve as Yes.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, President Joe Biden has declared his intention to seek re-election in the 2024 presidential race. There have been discussions and speculations about his age and potential health concerns, but there is no substantial evidence or official indication that he plans to announce that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination before July 15, 2024. Historically, incumbent presidents who seek re-election typically remain the party's nominee unless significant issues arise.

Regarding Kamala Harris's odds of winning increasing over the specified period according to Nate Silver's model: Unless President Biden steps down or announces he will not accept the nomination, Kamala Harris, the Vice President, is unlikely to become the Democratic nominee. Even if she were to become the nominee, there would need to be enough positive momentum and favorable polling data within that one-week window leading up to August 9th for her Electoral College odds to increase to over 46.6% in Nate Silver's model. This is a narrow time frame for significant changes in election forecasts.

Given the low probability of President Biden announcing his withdrawal before July 15, 2024, and the subsequent low likelihood of Kamala Harris's odds increasing in the specified manner, the chance that both events occur is very low.

question.title: Will either Joe Biden announce he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President before July 15, 2024, or Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body: (a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? This resolves as Yes if before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the nomination for a Yes resolution. (b) Will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model? Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday, August 9th, at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, President Joe Biden has announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024. While concerns about his age and health have been raised, there are no significant indications that he plans to withdraw from the race. Historically, incumbent presidents seldom decline their party's nomination unless faced with severe health issues or major political setbacks. Therefore, the probability of Joe Biden announcing before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination is relatively low, perhaps around 10%. Regarding Kamala Harris's odds of winning increasing over the next week according to Nate Silver's model (specifically exceeding 46.6% on August 9, 2024, at 8:40 PM), this scenario seems unlikely without significant political developments. As Vice President, Harris's electoral prospects are closely tied to Biden's candidacy. If Biden were to withdraw, her chances might improve, but absent that, substantial shifts in voter sentiment would be required. Given the lack of current data beyond my knowledge cutoff and the typically gradual changes in electoral odds, the probability of this occurring is also low, perhaps around 15%. Considering that these events could be interconnected (Biden stepping down could increase Harris's odds), the combined probability is slightly higher than the individual probabilities but still modest. Accounting for the dependency between the two events, I estimate the overall probability of either event (a) or event (b) occurring to be approximately 20%.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday?
question.body:
Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. 

Otherwise, resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Joe Biden is the President of the United States and was born on November 20, 1942, making him 80 years old at that time. By July 26, 2024, he will be 81 years old. According to actuarial life tables, the annual mortality rate for an 81-year-old male in the United States is approximately 7%. This means there is a 7% chance that an average 81-year-old male would pass away within one year.

However, the time frame in question is from now until July 26, 2024, which is roughly 9 months. Adjusting the annual mortality rate proportionally for a 9-month period gives:

\[\text{Adjusted Mortality Rate} = 1 - (1 - 0.07)^{\frac{9}{12}} \approx 5.3\%\]

Joe Biden has access to excellent healthcare, which might reduce his risk compared to the average person of his age. On the other hand, the stress associated with being the President could potentially increase health risks. Balancing these factors, it's reasonable to assume that his mortality risk is close to the average for his age group.

Therefore, the probability that Joe Biden will pass away before July 26, 2024, is approximately 5%.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, President Joe Biden is serving his first term as the President of the United States, with his term scheduled to end on January 20, 2025. He has announced his intention to run for re-election in the 2024 presidential race. There are several factors to consider when estimating the probability that he remains in office through the end of July 2024:

1. **Health and Age:** President Biden was born on November 20, 1942, making him 80 years old as of October 2023. By July 2024, he will be 81 years old. While age increases health risks, there have been no publicly disclosed serious health issues that suggest he is unfit to serve. The annual mortality rate for an 81-year-old male in the United States is approximately 5-6%. Considering the period between now and the end of July 2024 is about nine months, the mortality risk due to natural causes is roughly 3.75-4.5%. However, as the President, he has access to the best medical care, which may reduce this risk slightly.

2. **Resignation:** There are currently no indications that President Biden intends to resign before the end of his term. He has expressed commitment to his role and is actively preparing for the upcoming election. Political pressures or personal reasons prompting a sudden resignation appear unlikely at this time.

3. **Removal from Office:** Removal through impeachment and conviction is highly improbable. While there are political opponents who have called for his impeachment, the process requires a majority in the House of Representatives and a two-thirds majority in the Senate. As of now, the political composition of Congress makes this outcome unlikely.

4. **Other Risks:** The risk of assassination or other extraordinary events, while never zero, is minimal due to the extensive security measures in place.

**Conclusion:** Taking these factors into account, the probability that President Biden remains in office through the end of July 2024 is high. Accounting for the small risks associated with health and unforeseen events, a reasonable estimate would be a 95% chance that he remains President through the specified date.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday and remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: (a) There is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, and (b) Joe Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET). It resolves NO if either condition is not met. Note that a temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not affect the resolution of condition (b).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
For this question to resolve YES, two unlikely conditions must both be met: (a) There must be an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before the market closes on Friday, July 26th, 2024, and (b) Joe Biden must remain President through the end of July 2024. In other words, there needs to be an official death announcement, yet he continues to serve as President beyond that date.

Such a scenario would require an official announcement of his death that is later retracted or proven false, which is an extremely rare occurrence, especially for a sitting U.S. President. Additionally, there have been no historical precedents where a president was officially declared dead and then continued to serve in office.

Considering Joe Biden's age (he would be 81 in July 2024) and the possibility of health issues, the chance of an official death announcement is low but not zero. However, the probability that he remains President after such an announcement is exceedingly low.

Therefore, the combined probability of both events occurring within the specified timeframe is almost negligible.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden dies before Saturday, July 26th, 2024, or (b) Biden does not remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body:
(a) Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024. Otherwise, resolves NO.

(b) Resolves YES if Biden does not remain US President through the end of July 2024 (ET). This includes if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e., making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution, as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability that either (a) Joe Biden dies before Saturday, July 26th, 2024, or (b) he does not remain President through the end of July 2024, we'll consider several factors.

1. **Joe Biden's Age and Health**: As of October 2023, Joe Biden is 80 years old, born on November 20, 1942. According to actuarial life tables, the annual mortality rate for an 81-year-old male in the United States is approximately 7%. Given that the time frame is about 9 months from now until July 26th, 2024, the probability of death during this period is roughly proportional, around 5%. However, it's important to note that the President has access to excellent healthcare, which may slightly reduce this risk.

2. **Possibility of Resignation or Removal**: There are currently no indications that President Biden intends to resign before the end of July 2024. Additionally, the likelihood of impeachment and removal from office is low, barring any unforeseen significant events. Political stability factors and historical precedents suggest that mid-term presidential resignations or removals are rare.

3. **Combining Probabilities**: Since the events of death and leaving office (other than by death) are independent and both have low probabilities, we can sum these probabilities for an approximate total risk. The risk of death is about 5%, and the risk of resignation or removal is perhaps around 1% or less, leading to a combined probability of approximately 6%.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there have been legal efforts to remove or block Donald Trump from state primary ballots under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, which disqualifies individuals who have engaged in insurrection from holding public office. Lawsuits have been filed in states like Colorado and Minnesota seeking to invoke this clause due to Trump's alleged involvement in the events of January 6, 2021. However, no court has yet ruled to remove him from any ballot, and such a legal action would be unprecedented. The legal process is complex and would likely involve lengthy appeals that could extend beyond July 15, 2024. Additionally, removing a major candidate from the ballot poses significant constitutional and political challenges, and courts may be reluctant to set such a precedent without clear legislative guidance. Given these factors, while there is a possibility that Trump could be removed from a state's primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, it appears unlikely that this will occur and be in effect as of July 15, 2024.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Donald Trump is a leading candidate for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination. He has officially declared his candidacy and continues to hold substantial influence within the Republican Party. Several factors contribute to the likelihood of him securing the nomination:

1. **Polling Advantages**: Multiple national and state-level polls consistently show Donald Trump leading the Republican primary field by a significant margin. His support among Republican voters often surpasses 50%, indicating a strong base that is difficult for other candidates to overcome.

2. **Strong Support Base**: Trump maintains a loyal following that is highly engaged and motivated. This base has remained steadfast despite controversies and legal challenges, suggesting that his core support is resilient.

3. **Fundraising and Resources**: He has a substantial fundraising apparatus and a strong campaign infrastructure in place, providing him with the resources needed to run an effective primary campaign.

4. **Name Recognition**: As a former president, Trump has near-universal name recognition, which gives him an advantage over lesser-known candidates.

5. **Lack of Strong Alternatives**: While other candidates like Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and Mike Pence have entered the race, none have significantly closed the gap in polls or emerged as a unifying alternative within the party.

6. **Party Dynamics**: The Republican Party has, to a considerable extent, aligned with Trump's policy positions and rhetoric. His influence over party dynamics and voter priorities remains strong.

However, there are factors that could impact his chances:

1. **Legal Challenges**: Trump faces several legal issues, including indictments and ongoing investigations at both federal and state levels. Convictions or new charges could affect his candidacy or voter perceptions.

2. **Voter Fatigue**: Some segments within the Republican Party may seek new leadership or different approaches, potentially boosting other candidates.

3. **Unforeseen Events**: Health issues, major scandals, or significant shifts in the political landscape could alter the current trajectory.

Considering the strong indicators of support but accounting for the uncertainties, it is reasonable to estimate a high probability of Trump securing the nomination, while acknowledging that it is not a certainty.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Donald Trump is removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, and (b) Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
(a) This question will resolve as "Yes" if, on July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports, and not through speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements. The question resolves as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024. Note: This does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals after the date. If Trump is removed or blocked and then reinstated such that on July 15th he is not removed or blocked, the question resolves negatively.

(b) This question will resolve as "Yes" if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as "No". The question solely determines by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Donald Trump is the leading candidate for the Republican nomination for the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election. His substantial lead in polling suggests a high probability that he will be the Republican nominee, making event (b) likely to occur. Regarding event (a), there have been discussions and some legal actions aiming to disqualify Trump from the ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment due to his alleged involvement in the events of January 6, 2021. However, no state has officially removed or blocked him from the primary ballot as of the knowledge cutoff. The legal process to disqualify a candidate under this provision is complex and unprecedented at the presidential level, facing significant legal hurdles and likely appeals. Given the legal challenges and time constraints, the probability of Trump being removed or blocked from any state primary ballot under Section 3 by July 15, 2024, is low but not zero. Therefore, while event (b) is highly probable, the low likelihood of event (a) means the probability of both events occurring is low.

Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

The resolution is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, and not who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Donald Trump remains a prominent figure in U.S. politics and is a leading candidate for the Republican nomination for the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election. Polls consistently show him with a significant lead over other Republican contenders. His base of support within the Republican Party remains strong, and there have been numerous endorsements from influential party members.

Regarding condition (b), the likelihood of Trump becoming the Republican nominee is relatively high based on current trends. Historically, candidates with such strong early leads and widespread support within their party often secure the nomination. While there are other candidates in the race, none have matched his level of support up to this point.

Concerning condition (a), there have been discussions and legal actions in some states attempting to remove or block Trump from the ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, which addresses insurrection and the eligibility to hold office. However, as of October 2023, no state has officially removed him from the primary ballot on these grounds. Legal challenges of this nature are complex and can take considerable time to resolve. It's uncertain whether any state will succeed in this effort by July 15, 2024.

Given the high probability of condition (b) occurring and the uncertainty but potential possibility of condition (a), the overall probability that either condition will be met is substantial.

question.title: Will Biden drop out before July 20?
question.body: If Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, this market will resolve to no.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, President Joe Biden has officially declared his intention to run for re-election in 2024. He is the incumbent president and has the support of the Democratic Party. While there have been concerns about his age and mental acuity from some quarters, there have been no substantial indications that he plans to drop out of the race.

Given that President Biden is in his early 80s, there is a higher risk of health-related issues compared to younger candidates. According to actuarial tables, the annual mortality rate for an 81-year-old male in the United States is approximately 5%. Additionally, there is a possibility of serious but non-fatal health issues that could prevent him from continuing his campaign, which might add another 2-3% risk.

There is also a small chance of political developments that could lead to his withdrawal, such as significant shifts in party support or personal decisions, but these seem unlikely based on current information.

Combining these factors, the probability of President Biden dropping out or being unable to continue the race before July 20, 2024, is estimated to be around 7%.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Kamala Harris becomes President or Acting President by July 26, 2024? (b) Joe Biden drops out of the race before July 20, 2024?
question.body:
(a) Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. The primary resolution source for this component will be official information from the US government, with a consensus of credible reporting as a secondary source.

(b) Joe Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20, 2024, midnight Eastern Time. The resolution source for this component will be whether Biden drops out or is unable to continue the race by the specified date and time.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, President Joe Biden is serving as the President of the United States and has announced his intention to run for re-election in the 2024 presidential race, with Vice President Kamala Harris as his running mate. Here's an analysis of the two conditions:

(a) Kamala Harris becomes President or Acting President by July 26, 2024:

For Kamala Harris to become President or Acting President before July 26, 2024, one of the following would need to occur:

- Presidential Succession: If President Biden were to resign, be incapacitated, or pass away, the Vice President would assume the presidency. While President Biden is the oldest person to hold the office, there have been no reports of severe health issues that would make such an event likely within the specified timeframe.

- Temporary Transfer of Power: Under the 25th Amendment, the President can temporarily transfer power to the Vice President. This typically occurs during medical procedures requiring anesthesia. Such transfers are usually brief and pre-planned. While possible, they are rare and often last only a few hours.

Given the lack of indications of any imminent health concerns or plans for temporary power transfer, the probability of Kamala Harris becoming President or Acting President before July 26, 2024, is low but not zero.

(b) Joe Biden drops out of the race before July 20, 2024:

For President Biden to drop out of the 2024 race before July 20, 2024, scenarios include:

- Health Concerns: Significant health issues could compel him to withdraw. However, as with the previous point, there are no public indications of such concerns.

- Political Considerations: Unforeseen political events or shifts within the Democratic Party might lead to a withdrawal, but as of October 2023, he maintains substantial support within his party.

- Personal Reasons: Personal decisions could impact his candidacy, but there's no information suggesting this is likely.

Given these factors, the probability of President Biden dropping out before July 20, 2024, is also low.

Joint Probability of Both Events Occurring:

While both events are individually unlikely, they are somewhat correlated. If President Biden were to experience a severe health issue leading to incapacity, it could result in Kamala Harris becoming Acting President and potentially lead to Biden withdrawing from the race. However, the rarity of such events still makes the joint probability low.

Conclusion:

Taking into account the low individual probabilities and their partial correlation, I estimate the likelihood of both events occurring before their respective dates to be approximately 2%.

question.body: This question will resolve to "Yes" if either of the following occurs: (a) Vice President Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET, based on official information from the US government or a consensus of credible reporting; (b) Joe Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20, 2024, midnight Eastern Time. If neither event occurs, this question will resolve to "No."

There have been no significant public indications of health issues or political challenges that would lead him to drop out of the race before July 20, 2024. For Vice President Kamala Harris to become President or Acting President before July 26, 2024, an unforeseen event would need to occur, such as the invocation of the 25th Amendment due to the President's inability to discharge the powers and duties of his office, or the unfortunate possibility of death or severe incapacitation. Historically, such transfers of power are rare and typically temporary when they do occur (e.g., during medical procedures).

Given the low probability of President Biden dropping out of the race or being unable to continue his duties within the specified timeframe, combined with the absence of any current indicators pointing toward such outcomes, the likelihood of the question resolving to 'Yes' is low but not negligible due to unforeseen circumstances that can arise.

question.title: Will Nikki Haley be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Nikki Haley is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, the Republican primary race for the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election is underway. The field includes several candidates, but former President Donald Trump is the clear front-runner. Polls consistently show Trump with a significant lead nationally and in key early primary states. His base remains loyal despite ongoing legal challenges, and he has a strong hold on a significant portion of the Republican electorate.

Nikki Haley, the former Governor of South Carolina and former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, is also running for the nomination. She has participated in the Republican primary debates and has received positive feedback for her performances. Her policy positions appeal to a segment of the Republican base that seeks a traditional conservative alternative to Trump.

Factors influencing Nikki Haley's chances:

1. **Polling Numbers**: As of now, Haley is polling in single digits nationally, significantly behind Trump and behind other candidates like Ron DeSantis.

2. **Debate Performances**: Haley has had strong debate showings, which have the potential to boost her visibility and support. Improved name recognition could translate into higher polling numbers over time.

3. **Trump's Legal Issues**: Ongoing legal proceedings against Trump could impact his candidacy. If his legal situation worsens, it might lead some voters to consider alternative candidates.

4. **Primary Dynamics**: Early primary states like Iowa, New Hampshire, and South Carolina (Haley's home state) are crucial. A strong showing in these states could shift the momentum in her favor.

5. **Party Establishment Support**: Haley may receive backing from segments of the Republican establishment that are looking for a viable alternative to Trump.

Challenges for Haley:

- **Trump's Lead**: Overcoming Trump's substantial lead requires a significant shift in voter sentiment.
  
- **Voter Loyalty**: Trump's supporters have remained steadfast, and it's unclear how much of his base would shift to another candidate.

- **Competition from Other Candidates**: Other candidates like Ron DeSantis and Vivek Ramaswamy are also vying for the non-Trump segment of the electorate.

Considering these factors, while there are scenarios where Nikki Haley could become the nominee—particularly if unexpected events significantly alter the race dynamics—the probability remains low given the current state of the race.

question.title: Will Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Glenn Youngkin is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, the Republican primary for the 2024 US Presidential Election is heavily influenced by former President Donald Trump, who remains the clear frontrunner in national polls among Republican voters. Other declared candidates include Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, former South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley, entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy, and others who have been campaigning for months but have not significantly closed the gap with Trump.

Glenn Youngkin, the Governor of Virginia since January 2022, has gained national attention after his unexpected victory in a state that has recently leaned Democratic. His focus on education, parental rights, and moderate conservative policies has made him a rising star within the Republican Party. There has been speculation and some encouragement from major Republican donors and strategists for Youngkin to consider entering the presidential race, particularly as concerns grow about Trump's legal challenges and general election viability.

However, as of now, Youngkin has not declared his candidacy for the presidency. The logistical challenges of entering the race at this late stage are significant. Filing deadlines for primary ballots in key states are approaching or have already passed, making it difficult to launch a viable campaign infrastructure. Additionally, building national name recognition and securing endorsements would be challenging with limited time.

Even if Youngkin were to enter the race, unseating Trump as the nominee would be an uphill battle. Trump's base remains loyal, and no current candidate has made substantial inroads into his support. While a contested convention or a significant shift in the political landscape could theoretically open a path for someone like Youngkin, these scenarios are unlikely.

In summary, while Glenn Youngkin is a prominent figure within the Republican Party and has potential for future national office, the probability of him becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 Presidential Election is very low given the current circumstances.

question.title: Will both Nikki Haley and Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Nikki Haley and Glenn Youngkin are selected by the Republican National Convention as nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, former President Donald Trump is leading the Republican primary polls by a significant margin. Nikki Haley, while officially running for the nomination, is polling far behind Trump and is considered a long-shot candidate for the top of the ticket. Glenn Youngkin, the Governor of Virginia, has not officially declared his candidacy for the presidency. While there has been speculation about Youngkin entering the race or being considered for the vice-presidential slot, there is no definitive indication that this will happen.

The Republican National Convention selects both the presidential and vice-presidential nominees. However, the vice-presidential nominee is typically chosen by the presidential nominee rather than through delegate votes. Given Trump's strong position, it is unlikely that both Haley and Youngkin will be the nominees. The scenario where Haley secures the presidential nomination and selects Youngkin as her running mate is highly improbable due to her current standing in the polls. Conversely, if Youngkin were to enter the race late, the chances of both him and Haley being on the ticket are still minimal.

Considering these factors, the probability that both Nikki Haley and Glenn Youngkin will be selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominees for president and vice president is extremely low.

question.title: Will either Nikki Haley or Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Nikki Haley or Glenn Youngkin is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, the Republican primary field for the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election is led by former President Donald Trump, who holds a significant lead in national polls. His support among Republican voters remains strong despite ongoing legal challenges. National polling averages indicate that Trump has around 50-60% support among likely Republican primary voters.

Nikki Haley, the former Governor of South Carolina and former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, has declared her candidacy and has been actively campaigning. She has performed well in primary debates and has seen a modest increase in her polling numbers. Currently, she polls in the single digits to low teens nationally, placing her behind Trump and, in some polls, behind Florida Governor Ron DeSantis.

Glenn Youngkin, the Governor of Virginia, has not declared his candidacy for the Republican nomination as of October 2023. While there has been speculation about a potential late entry, he has not taken official steps toward launching a campaign. His national profile is rising due to his gubernatorial accomplishments and media appearances, but his absence from the race limits his immediate chances.

Considering these factors:

- **Donald Trump's Dominance**: Trump's lead suggests he is the frontrunner. Unless his legal issues prevent him from continuing, he is likely to secure the nomination.
  
- **Nikki Haley's Position**: Haley is gaining some traction but remains well behind Trump. Her experience and favorable debate performances could boost her standing, but overcoming Trump's lead is challenging.
  
- **Glenn Youngkin's Potential Entry**: Youngkin's chances hinge on whether he enters the race. A late entry is possible, especially if party leaders seek an alternative to Trump and DeSantis. However, building a national campaign infrastructure in a short time is difficult.
  
- **Uncertainties**: Legal challenges facing Trump could alter the race. If Trump withdraws or is impeded, the nomination contest would become more open, potentially increasing opportunities for other candidates like Haley or Youngkin.

Estimating probabilities:

- **Probability of Trump securing the nomination**: Approximately 70%
- **Probability of Trump being unable to continue his campaign**: Approximately 10%
- **Probability allocated to other candidates**: 30% (100% - 70% Trump's likelihood)

Within that 30%:

- **Ron DeSantis**: Approximately 10%
- **Nikki Haley**: Approximately 8%
- **Glenn Youngkin**: Approximately 2%
- **Other candidates**: Approximately 10%

Therefore, the combined probability of either Nikki Haley or Glenn Youngkin becoming the Republican nominee is:

- **Nikki Haley (8%) + Glenn Youngkin (2%) = 10%**

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there have been legal efforts in several states to remove or block Donald Trump from the primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. This section prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding public office. The argument is based on Trump's alleged involvement in the events of January 6, 2021, at the U.S. Capitol.

However, successfully invoking Section 3 to disqualify a candidate is legally complex and unprecedented in modern times. Here are key factors influencing the likelihood of Trump being removed from any state's primary ballot under this provision by July 15, 2024:

1. Legal Precedent and Interpretation:
   - Limited Precedent: There is minimal contemporary precedent for applying Section 3 to modern candidates. The most notable cases date back to the post-Civil War era.
   - Constitutional Questions: Courts may be hesitant to set a new precedent on such a significant constitutional matter without clear guidance, especially involving a former president.

2. Judicial Process and Timing:
   - Lengthy Legal Proceedings: Lawsuits challenging Trump’s eligibility are likely to face extended litigation, including appeals that could reach the Supreme Court.
   - Time Constraints: Given the slow pace of the judicial process, final resolutions may not occur before July 15, 2024.

3. Political and Public Considerations:
   - Voter Disenfranchisement Concerns: Courts may consider the implications of removing a leading candidate from the ballot on voters' rights.
   - Political Pressure: High-profile cases can be influenced by political dynamics, potentially swaying judicial decisions.

4. State Variations:
   - Differences in State Laws: Election laws vary by state, affecting how and whether Section 3 can be applied.
   - States Pursuing Actions: While some states may be more inclined to pursue these legal challenges, as of now, no state has officially removed Trump from the ballot under Section 3.

5. Defenses and Counterarguments:
   - Legal Defense: Trump's legal team is expected to vigorously contest any attempts to disqualify him, arguing issues such as the definition of "insurrection" and applicability to his actions.
   - First Amendment Rights: Defense may argue that disqualification infringes on free speech and political participation rights.

6. Historical Context:
   - Past Attempts: Previous efforts to disqualify candidates under Section 3 in recent decades have not been successful.
   - Implications for Democracy: Courts may be cautious about making decisions that could be perceived as undermining democratic processes.

Considering these factors, while there is a possibility that at least one state might attempt to remove Trump from the primary ballot under Section 3, the likelihood of such an action being finalized and in effect by July 15, 2024, is relatively low. The combination of legal complexities, appeals, and the importance of safeguarding electoral processes suggests that Trump will remain on the ballot in all states through the primary season up to that date.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, and will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met:

(a) As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

(b) Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To determine the probability that the question resolves as "Yes," we need to assess the likelihood of both conditions (a) and (b) being met by the specified dates.

**(a) Donald Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024:**

As of my knowledge cutoff in September 2023, there have been discussions among legal scholars, politicians, and activists about the possibility of invoking Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify Donald Trump from holding federal office due to his actions related to the January 6th, 2021 Capitol riot. Some lawsuits and petitions may be filed to challenge his eligibility.

However, removing a major party candidate from the ballot is unprecedented and would face significant legal hurdles, including constitutional challenges that would likely escalate to higher courts. The judicial process is often lengthy, and it's uncertain whether such cases could be resolved in favor of removal by July 15, 2024. Additionally, Trump's strong support base within the Republican Party might discourage states from pursuing such actions.

Given these factors, the probability of Trump being officially removed or blocked from any state's primary ballot under Section 3 by the specified date is low but not negligible.

**(b) Ted Cruz being selected as the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election:**

As of September 2023, Ted Cruz has not announced a presidential campaign for the 2024 election. The leading contenders for the Republican nomination are generally considered to be Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis. Ted Cruz would need to announce his candidacy, build a significant campaign infrastructure, and surpass other candidates who may have more momentum or support.

The probability of Ted Cruz becoming the nominee is affected by several factors:

- **Entry into the Race:** Without an official campaign, his chances are minimal.
- **Party Dynamics:** The Republican Party landscape currently favors other candidates.
- **Time Constraints:** With the primary season approaching, late entries face hurdles in fundraising and gaining voter support.

Considering these elements, the likelihood of Ted Cruz being selected as the nominee is quite low.

**Combined Probability:**

Both conditions (a) and (b) must occur for the question to resolve as "Yes." The low probabilities of each event multiply to create an even smaller combined probability.

question.title: Will either Donald Trump be removed from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment or Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if either of the following occurs:

(a) Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

(b) Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, not by who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election. All other candidates will resolve as "No". This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

The question will resolve as "No" if neither condition (a) nor condition (b) is met.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there have been legal efforts to disqualify Donald Trump from appearing on ballots under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment due to his actions related to the January 6th Capitol riot. While some advocacy groups and individuals have filed lawsuits in various states seeking to remove him from the ballot, no state has officially removed or blocked him from the primary election ballot under these grounds. Legal challenges of this nature are unprecedented and would likely face significant obstacles, including appeals that could reach the Supreme Court. Given the complexity and high legal threshold required, it is unlikely that Trump will be officially removed from any state's primary ballot by July 15, 2024. Regarding Ted Cruz, he has not announced a campaign for the 2024 presidential election. The current Republican primary field is dominated by candidates like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and Nikki Haley. Ted Cruz has not been prominently mentioned as a potential nominee, and there is no significant indication that he will be selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 election. Considering both factors, the probability that either Donald Trump will be removed from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment or that Ted Cruz will be the Republican nominee is low.

question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, Mike Pence is a declared candidate for the Republican nomination in the 2024 US Presidential Election. However, he has consistently polled in the low single digits, significantly trailing behind the leading candidates. Former President Donald Trump holds a substantial lead in most polls, with Florida Governor Ron DeSantis and former UN Ambassador Nikki Haley also ahead of Pence.

Mike Pence's tenure as Vice President under Trump has not translated into strong support among Republican voters for his own presidential bid. Factors such as his break with Trump over the certification of the 2020 election results have affected his standing within the party's base. Additionally, limited fundraising and lower visibility compared to other candidates make it challenging for him to gain momentum.

Given these factors—the low polling numbers, limited support within the party base, and strong competition from frontrunners—it is unlikely that Mike Pence will be selected by the delegates at the Republican National Convention as the nominee.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if the United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Analyzing the historical performance of the United States Olympic Team in recent Summer Olympics provides insight into this question. Here are the medal counts for the last four Summer Olympics:

- **2008 Beijing**: 36 Gold, 38 Silver
- **2012 London**: 46 Gold, 28 Silver
- **2016 Rio de Janeiro**: 46 Gold, 37 Silver
- **2020 Tokyo**: 39 Gold, 41 Silver

In two of these four Olympics (2012 and 2016), the USA won more gold medals than silver medals. In the other two (2008 and 2020), they won more silver medals than gold medals. This suggests a relatively even likelihood of either outcome based on recent history.

Factors to consider:

- **Athlete Performance and Development**: The USA continues to invest heavily in athlete training and development programs. Young and emerging athletes may contribute to higher gold medal counts.
  
- **Competition**: Other countries are also improving, potentially making it harder for the USA to secure gold medals in traditionally strong events.
  
- **Event Outcomes**: Small differences in performance can sway medal outcomes from gold to silver or vice versa.

Given the historical data and these factors, there is significant uncertainty. The likelihood of the USA winning more gold than silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics appears to be approximately equal.

question.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team.

The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, here is my analysis:

1. **Historical Performance**:
   - The United States has consistently been a top performer in the Summer Olympics. In the 2021 Tokyo Olympics, the USA topped the medal table with 39 gold medals, narrowly edging out China, which had 38 gold medals.
   - Historically, the USA has frequently led the medal count, leveraging its extensive athlete development programs and strong participation across a wide range of sports.

2. **Key Competitors**:
   - **China**: China's Olympic performance has been steadily improving over the past few decades. They are the most significant threat to the USA topping the medal table. In Tokyo 2021, the competition was very close.
   - **Russia**: Russia's participation has been affected by doping sanctions. Depending on their status in 2024, they could impact the medal standings if allowed to compete fully.
   - **Host Nation (France)**: While host nations often see a boost in performance due to home advantage, France has not historically been a top contender for the number one spot in the medal table.

3. **Factors Affecting 2024 Performance**:
   - **Athlete Development**: The USA continues to invest heavily in sports infrastructure and athlete development, which should maintain their competitive edge.
   - **Emerging Sports**: The addition of new sports like skateboarding and sport climbing has benefited countries like the USA. Continuation or expansion of such sports may favor the USA.
   - **Global Events**: Barring unforeseen events (e.g., pandemics, geopolitical issues), there should be minimal disruptions affecting athletes' preparations.

4. **Potential Risks**:
   - **China's Investment**: China's significant investment in sports could lead to improved performance, potentially surpassing the USA.
   - **Tie Possibility**: Given the narrow margin in the last Olympics, there's a realistic possibility of a tie in gold, silver, and bronze medal counts, which would result in a negative resolution per the question's criteria.
   - **Other Nations**: While less likely, other nations could have breakout performances that impact the medal rankings.

5. **Probability of Olympics Occurring Before 2027**:
   - It is highly likely that the Paris 2024 Olympics will take place as scheduled, given current global conditions and progress in pandemic management.

**Conclusion**:

Considering the USA's historical dominance but acknowledging the rising challenges from China and potential for ties, there is a strong but not certain likelihood that the USA will be the unique highest ranked team at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals and top the Olympic Medal Table at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (a) The United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics. (b) The United States Olympic Team is the unique highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. The ranking is determined by the number of Gold Medals won, followed by Silver Medals, and then Bronze Medals in case of ties. The question will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that the USA will win more Gold than Silver medals and top the Olympic Medal Table at the Paris 2024 Olympics, we'll consider historical data, current trends, and potential competitors.

1. **Historical Performance:**
   - **Gold vs. Silver Medals:**
     - *Tokyo 2020:* 39 Gold, 41 Silver (more Silvers than Golds)
     - *Rio 2016:* 46 Gold, 37 Silver (more Golds than Silvers)
     - *London 2012:* 46 Gold, 28 Silver (more Golds than Silvers)
     - *Beijing 2008:* 36 Gold, 38 Silver (more Silvers than Golds)
     - Over the past four Olympics, the USA had more Golds than Silvers in two out of four occasions.
   - **Topping the Medal Table:**
     - The USA topped the medal table in Tokyo 2020, Rio 2016, and London 2012.
     - China was a close competitor, especially in Beijing 2008 where they topped the medal table.

2. **Current Trends and Factors:**
   - **Athlete Development:**
     - The USA has a strong sports infrastructure and continues to produce top-tier athletes in swimming, athletics, gymnastics, and other sports.
     - Emerging talents and seasoned athletes are expected to compete in Paris 2024.
   - **Competitors:**
     - **China:** A major competitor with significant investment in sports development.
     - **ROC/Russia:** Depending on participation status due to doping sanctions.
     - **Great Britain and Host Nation (France):** May have strong performances but historically lag behind the USA in total Golds.
   - **External Factors:**
     - Changes in event lineups, athlete injuries, or global events (e.g., pandemics) could impact outcomes.

3. **Probability Assessment:**
   - **Winning More Gold than Silver Medals:**
     - Given historical data (50% occurrence in the last four Olympics) and current athlete prospects, there's an estimated **55% chance** the USA will achieve more Golds than Silvers.
   - **Topping the Medal Table:**
     - The USA has a strong track record and depth in many sports, leading to an estimated **75% chance** of topping the medal table.
   - **Combined Probability:**
     - Since these two events are related (winning more Golds increases the likelihood of topping the medal table), we can estimate the combined probability.
     - **Combined Estimated Probability:** Approximately **65%** chance that both conditions are met.

question.title: Will either of the following occur at the Paris 2024 Olympics: (a) The USA wins more Gold than Silver medals (b) The USA tops the Olympic Medal Table?
question.body:
(a) This resolves Yes if the United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

(b) This resolves Yes if the United States Olympic Team is the unique highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It resolves ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It resolves No if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team. The medal table is calculated by:
1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that either (a) the USA wins more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics, or (b) the USA tops the Olympic Medal Table, we'll analyze historical data and recent trends.

Event (a): USA wins more Gold than Silver medals
- Historical Performance: In the last five Summer Olympics:  
  - Tokyo 2020: 39 Gold, 41 Silver (No)  
  - Rio 2016: 46 Gold, 37 Silver (Yes)  
  - London 2012: 46 Gold, 28 Silver (Yes)  
  - Beijing 2008: 36 Gold, 38 Silver (No)  
  - Athens 2004: 35 Gold, 39 Silver (No)  
- Probability Estimate: The USA had more Gold than Silver medals in 2 out of the last 5 Olympics, suggesting a historical probability of 40% for this event.  
- Current Trends: The competition is increasing, particularly from countries like China, making it moderately likely for the USA to achieve more Gold than Silver medals.

Event (b): USA tops the Olympic Medal Table
- Historical Performance: The USA topped the medal table in 4 out of the last 5 Olympics.  
  - Exception: Beijing 2008, where China topped the medal table.  
- Probability Estimate: Based on historical data, there's approximately an 80% chance of the USA topping the medal table.  
- Current Trends: Despite increasing competition, the USA maintains strong athletic programs and depth across many sports, supporting a high likelihood of topping the medal table.

Combined Probability
- Correlation Between Events: These events are somewhat correlated; topping the medal table often involves winning a significant number of Gold medals.  
- Calculating Probability:  
  - Probability of (a): 45%  
  - Probability of (b): 80%  
  - Probability of Both (a and b): Since having more Gold than Silver medals often contributes to topping the medal table, we'll estimate this at 40%.  
  - Probability of Either Event Occurring:  
    - P(a or b) = P(a) + P(b) - P(a and b)  
    - P(a or b) = 0.45 + 0.80 - 0.40 = 0.85  
- Conclusion: There's an estimated 85% probability that either the USA will win more Gold than Silver medals, or the USA will top the Olympic Medal Table at the Paris 2024 Olympics.
